question.body: What are the four application domains?

answer.body: Embedded systems, scientific software systems, cyber-physical systems, information systems

question.body: What is an embedded system?

answer.body: A computer system part of a larger system performing some requirements of the system.

question.body: What are some characteristics of embedded systems?
What are three important quality attributes of (real-time) embedded systems?

answer.body: Dependability, efficiency, real-time

question.body: What type of constraint ist added in a real time system? What aspect is important?

answer.body: Timing constraints. Predictability is very important.

question.body: What is a reactive system?

answer.body: A reactive system is one which is in continual interaction with its environment and executes at a pace determined by the environment (typically ES are also reactive).

question.body: What is an information system?

answer.body: An integrated set of components for collecting, storing, processing data and for delivering information, knowledge, digital products.

question.body: What type of information systems are there?

answer.body: Transaction processing systems (repetitive, high-volume tasks), management information systems (support routine decision making in functional areas), decision support (complex non-routine decision making support), end-user computing (systems for use by users such as analysts, managers, other professionals), office automation systems (automate office tasks), intelligent support systems (expert systems), knowledge management systems, data warehousing, enterprise resource planning, mobile computing, e-business and e-commerce.

question.body: What is a cyber-physical system?

answer.body: A socio-technical system that integrates information systems, embedded systems, and humans.

question.body: What is software engineering?

answer.body: A collection of techniques, methodologies and tools that aid the product of a high quality software system with a given budget before a given deadline while change occurs.

question.body: What is a process model?

answer.body: It describes the systematic, engineering-based, and quantifiable approach to solve a particular class of repeatable problems. It is an abstract representation of the software process.

question.body: What process models are covered in the lecture?

answer.body: Waterfall model, V-model, spiral-model, unified process, scrum

question.body: What are two problems with the waterfall model?

answer.body: It is inflexible due to the strictly sequential process and it is risky because it detects problems late.

question.body: What are the concepts behind the spiral model and what is the aim?

answer.body: Incremental, iterative development and evolutionary models to minimize risk.

question.body: What is emphasized in the unified process and what are the essential components?

answer.body: Places emphasis on construction of architecture and early demonstrations. Has 4 phases (inception, elaboration, construction, transition), 7 workflows (management, environment, requirements, design, implementation, assessment, deployment), and 5 artifact sets (management set, requirements set, design set, implementation set, deployment set). Based on iteration.

question.body: What are the four paradigms of agile development?

answer.body: Individuals and interactions over processes and tools. Working software over comprehensive documentation, customer collaboration over contract negotiation. Responding to change over following a plan.

question.body: What are the essential components of scrum?

answer.body: Product requirements are collected in the product backlog. Development is divided into sprints with sprint planning and retrospective meetings. Daily standup meetings are held. There are three roles: product owner, development team, and scum master

question.body: What are some issues with the agile approach?

answer.body: Scalability, feature interaction, maintainability, technical debt.

question.body: What are some artifacts generated in requirements engineering?

answer.body: Feasibility report, system models, user and system requirements, requirements document

question.body: What are some input/output artifacts in software design?

answer.body: Input: Platform information, requirements specification, data description. Output: System architecture, database specification, interface specification, component specification.

question.body: What are some artifacts generated in testing?

answer.body: Acceptance test plan, system integration test plan, sub-system integration test plan.

question.body: What is software quality?

answer.body: All characteristics of a software product that influence its ability to fulfill specified requirements and stakeholder expectations (can refer to both process and product).

question.body: What is the difference between quality and non-functional requirements?

answer.body: Quality = Process Quality + Product Quality (NFRs)

question.body: What types of interdependencies between quality aspects exist? Which one is problematic?

answer.body: Positive: improving one aspects improves another. Negative: improving one aspect interferes with the other. The negative correlation causes issues that need to be solved in tradeoffs.

question.body: What are some intrinsic quality aspects according to ISO 9126?

answer.body: Correctness and completeness.

question.body: What are some design-time quality aspects according to ISO 9126?

answer.body: Portability (adaptability, installability, co-existence, replaceability) and maintainability (analyzability, learnability, changeability, reusability, stability, testability).

question.body: What are some run-time quality aspects according to ISO 9126?

answer.body: Usability, reliability, efficiency, functionality

question.body: What are the categories of quality in the ISO 9126 model, what type of quality do they refer to and from which perspective can they be analyzed?

answer.body: Intrinsic, design-time, run-time. Refers to both external/internal quality and can be analyzed from black/white-box perspective.

question.body: Which four factors influence product quality?

answer.body: Process quality, development technology, cost-, time- and schedule constraints, people quality.

question.body: What problem can be encountered when assessing quality?

answer.body: Many quality attributes are hard to measure directly.

question.body: What two types of quality standards are there?

answer.body: Product standards: characteristics present in all components. Process standards: define how software process should be enacted.

question.body: What is required for an organization to be ISO 9001 conformant?

answer.body: It needs to document how its processes relate to the nine core processes (product delivery processes and supporting processes).

question.body: What are some problems with the ISO 9001 quality standard?

answer.body: Certification does not imply increased software quality. Standard focuses on ensuring quality management procedures are in place, not that they work. ISO 9001 defines quality by conformance to standards, not taking into account quality as experienced by the users.

question.body: What is an embedded system and some of it's common attributes?

answer.body: Example Definitions: Real-time system, small microcontroller with little memory, programmed in assembler or in C. Information system that is integrated into a larger product.

question.body: Define software architecture.

answer.body: Example definitions: 1: The fundamental organization of a system embodied in its components, their relationships to each other, and to the environment, and the principles guiding its design and evolution. 4: Architecture is a set of significant design decisions that shape a system.

question.body: What is the purpose of software architecture?

answer.body: Quality, Efficiency, Risk Minimization, Communication Means, Knowledge Management.

question.body: What is a system?

answer.body: A collection of components organized to accomplish a set of functions with defined boundaries, components and interfaces, environment interaction and static structure and dynamic behavior

question.body: What is a system's environment?

answer.body: The developmental, operational, political and other influences on the system

question.body: What is an architectural description?

answer.body: A document recording the architecture of a system

question.body: What are two key roles among stakeholders?

answer.body: The principal and the architect.

question.body: What is a stakeholder?

answer.body: An entity with interest in, or concerns relative to, the system that has varios roles with regard to creation/use of the architectural descriptions.

question.body: What is a concern in relation to software architecture? What are some typical concerns?

answer.body: An interest which pertains to the system's development, its operation, or any other aspect important to stakeholders. Includes considerations such as performance, reliability, security, distribution, evolvability.

question.body: What is the difference between a view and a viewpoint?

answer.body: View: Document addressing concerns of stakeholders conforming to a viewpoint. Viewpoint: Determines language (notation etc.) and any modeling methods or analysis techniques to be used to describe the view.

question.body: What is an architecture rationale?

answer.body: The explanation/justification for an architecture decision including documentation for the chosen and not-chosen architecture alternatives

question.body: What views are part of the 4+1 view model? How are they classified?

answer.body: Logical view (conceptual), process view (conceptual), implementation view (physical), deployment view (physical), use case view (both).

question.body: What does the logical viewpoint describe in the 4+1 model?

answer.body: It describes the design's functionality from an end user perspective.

question.body: What does the process viewpoint describe in the 4+1 model?

answer.body: It describes the dynamic communication, concurrency, and synchronization aspects

question.body: What does the deployment viewpoint describe in the 4+1 model?

answer.body: The mapping of software onto hardware, reflecting the distributed aspects.

question.body: What does the implementation view describe in the 4+1 model?

answer.body: The software's static organization in its development environment.

question.body: What is a scenario in the 4+1 view model?

answer.body: A scenario (use-case) is used to show that the elements of the four viewpoints work seamlessly together.

question.body: What does the 4+1 stand for in the 4+1 view model

answer.body: The 4+1 different viewpoints

question.body: What diagrams are typically used for the logical, process, implementation, deployment, and use case view in the 4+1 model?

answer.body: Logical: class diagram, process: sequence diagram, implementation: component, deployment: deployment diagram

question.body: What are the four parts of the C4 model and what do they focus on?

answer.body: System context diagram: Focus on people and software systems. Container diagram: Shows high level shape of the architecture and the distribution of responsibilities, as well as technology choices and communication between containers. Component diagram: Decomposes a container into components, including responsibilities and technology/implementation choices. Code diagram: Class diagrams or entity-relationship diagrams.

question.body: What is the idea behind the C4 model?

answer.body: Precise notation is much less important than efficiently communicating the architecture to the target audience.

question.body: What types of system models are there and what do they describe?

answer.body: Object model: Describes the structure of the system and relationships between objects. Functional model: Describes the functions of the system and data flow through the system. Dynamic model: Describes how the system reacts to external events and how events flow through the system.

question.body: What are the three main attributes characterizing models?

answer.body: Reduction: An increase in abstraction leads to easier communication. Pragmatism: A model is created with a purpose in mind. Mapping: There is a relationship between elements in the model and elements in the original.

question.body: What do you call models that represent the current state of a system and the planned state of a system?

answer.body: As-is models describe the current situation, to-be models the planned state once the project is finished.

question.body: What are the seven stages in the cycle of modeling?

answer.body: Understand (Comprehend the problem and possible solutions), Conceptualize (Formalize parts of the application domain into a concept language), Abstract (generalize and outline main problems), Define (Unambiguously specify concepts), Construct (actually create the model), Evaluate (based on quality characteristics), Refine (iterate)

question.body: Draw the UML diagram of the IEEE 471 standard.

answer.body: See Chapter 2.1.1 slide 6

question.body: What are some of the benefity of modularity?

answer.body: Easier maintenance, reusability, understandability, reduced complexity, allows for work distribution.

question.body: What is modularity?

answer.body: A decomposition of systems into modules that measures the degree to which components can be separated and recombined.

question.body: What is functional decomposition and what are some of its issues?

answer.body: Each module is a major processing step (function) in the application domain, which can be decomposed into smaller modules. Some issues include the spread of functionality all over the system and the need to understand the whole system to make changes to it, which leads to understandability and maintainability problems.

question.body: What is a modular decomposition? What assumptions are made and what are some limitations?

answer.body: Each module represents a major abstraction in the application domain. Assumptions: It is possible to find concepts for a new system (greenfield engineering), an existing system (re-engineering), and we can create component-based interfaces for any system (interface engineering). Limitations: Non-unique, different concepts might be found for the same system.

question.body: What is a black-box model?

answer.body: A black box model presents the functional perspective on a system. Only the interaction between the composition and the environment are taken into account in an abstract way.

question.body: What is a white-box model?

answer.body: A white box model presents the construction perspective on a system, capturing construction and operation.

question.body: What are the three steps to decompose a system?

answer.body: Step 1: Analyze dependencies between elements. Step 2: Elements with strong dependencies form components. Step 3: Dependencies between components are captured in interfaces.

question.body: What is a software component?

answer.body: Def 1: A software element conforming to a component model that can be independently deployed and composed according to a composition standard. Def 2: A unit of composition with contractually specified interfaces and explicit context dependencies only that can be deploed independently and is subject to composition by third parties.

question.body: What is component-based software engineering? What shortcoming of object-orientation does it fix?

answer.body: An approach to software development relying on reuse of entities (software components). It emerged because object-orientation tends to be too detailed and specific for effective reuse. A component is an independent executable entity made up of executable objects. The interface is published and all interactions are made through the published interface.

question.body: What are some characteristics of software components?

answer.body: They are standardized (conforms to a standard component model), independent (possibility to compose and deploy by itself), composable, deployable and documented.

question.body: What is a component model?

answer.body: A definition of standards for component implementation, documentation, and deployment.

question.body: What are the basic elements of a component model?

answer.body: Interface definition, language used, naming conventions, meta-data, packaging

question.body: What are the types of component compositions and how do they work?

answer.body: Sequential composition: An intermediate hooks into the exposed components of multiple interfaces. Hierarchical composition: One component hooks into the exposed interface of another component. Adaptive composition: A wrapper surrounds the internal components and wraps around the incoming and outgoing dependencies.

question.body: What are some of the benefits of component based software engineering?

answer.body: Independent components, standardized components, middleware, development process geared to reuse.

question.body: What are some cons of component-based software engineering?

answer.body: Trustworthiness of external components, certification of components, emergent property prediction, requirements trade-offs

question.body: What is design by contract?

answer.body: A set of principles to produce dependable and robust object-oriented software

question.body: What are the two major characteristics of a contract in the design by contract principle?

answer.body: 1: Each party expects benefits from the contract and is prepared to incur obligations to obtain them. These are documented in the contract document, and no other obligations can be can be imposed (no-hidden-clauses rule) to obtain the benefits.

question.body: What are the pre/post conditions in a design-by-contract environment?

answer.body: They are assertions (expressions that evaluate to true or false), checking the requirements that any call must satisfy/the properties ensured at the end of execution of the procedure.

question.body: Give an example of a language with builtin design-by-contract functionality

answer.body: The Eiffel programming language

question.body: What are some of the principles in design by contract?

answer.body: 1: Non-redundancy principle (The routine never checks its own precondition). 2: Reasonable precondition principle (the need is justified and documented). 3: Failure principle (execution of rescue clause to end, not leading to a retry, causes call to fail. 4: Disciplined exception handling principle (retry / failure) 5: Exception simplicity principle (rescue clauses are simple and focus only on obtaining a stable state.

question.body: What is the difference between defensive programming and design by contract?

answer.body: Defensive programming promotes putting checks in every module to detect unexpected situations. This can lead to redundant checks (duplication) and the responsibilities are less well defined.

question.body: What is the meaning of an entry (row/column) in the dependency structure matrix?

answer.body: The row depends on the column.

question.body: What is a dependency structure matrix?

answer.body: A 2D matrix representing structural/functional interrelationships of objects, tasks, or teams

question.body: What is partitioning in relation to a DSM?

answer.body: The collapsing of mutual dependent components into a group to transform the matrix into block triangular form.

question.body: What property does the lower triangular DSM ensure?

answer.body: That dependencies are acyclic.

question.body: How is a hierarchical DSM different from a normal DSM?

answer.body: In a hierarchical DSM, groups are represented by a border instead of collapsed into one.

question.body: How can a layered software system be detected in a DSM?

answer.body: Lower triangular form (each component accesses functionality somewhere below it).

question.body: How can a strictly layered software system be detected in a DSM?

answer.body: Only entries adjacent to one side of the diagonal.

question.body: What is the meaning of a change propagator in a DSM?

answer.body: A component that is dependent on/depends on many other components. A change in one of the components it depends on can also affect all components that depend on it.

question.body: What are some of the benefits of using a DSM?

answer.body: Better scaling than box-and-line diagrams, helps better understand flow of information, automatic mechanism for architectural discovery, efficient cycle detection and integration of dependency rules.

question.body: What are some challenges of a DSM?

answer.body: Only as good as knowledge that goes into it. Unknown interdependencies can exist. Less intuitive than a graph.

question.body: What is the formal definition of the structure of a system?

answer.body: The formal definition of a structure is defined by S:=(C,I,CON), where C denotes the components, env\in C denotes the environment, I denoting the interfaces and CON\subseteq I\cross I the connection between interfaces. A component can be a system itself.

question.body: What are the types of relationship in a system structure?

answer.body: Parent relationships (C\rightarrow C, parent(a)=env), Interface-component relationship (I\rightarrow C, assigned(i)=a), connections between interfaces (CON\rightarrow I\cross I, connected(c)=(a,b))

question.body: How is coupling calculated?

answer.body: coupling(S):=\alpha * percentage of connections on same level + (1-\alpha) * percentage of connections on different levels. Where \alpha is a weighting factor of choice.

question.body: What are the types of coupling in order of decreasing coupling (lower is better)?

answer.body: Content, Common, External, Control, Stamp, Data

question.body: What is the meaning of content coupling?

answer.body: One component directly affects the working of another component by modifying its data or passing control to unintended points in the other component. Any modification in the other component usually requires a modification in this component.

question.body: What is the meaning of common coupling?

answer.body: Two components use shared data (global variables etc). This leads to a lack of clear data responsibility, reduced readability, reduced maintainability, difficulties in reuse and a reduced ability to control data access.

question.body: What is the meaning of external coupling?

answer.body: Components communicate through an external medium (file, device, protocol, data format)

question.body: What is the meaning of control coupling?

answer.body: One component directs control to another component by passing control information. Good if paramenters allow factoring and reuse, bad if parameters cause completely different behavior or require knowledge of internal functions.

question.body: What is the meaning of stamp coupling?

answer.body: In stamp coupling, complete data structures are passed between components. The second component therefore has more information that it needs. Define interfaces to limit what clients can access.

question.body: What is the meaning of data coupling?

answer.body: Component passes only data (not data structures) to another component. Ensures the other component can only access information that it actually needs.

question.body: What is the meaning of Cohesion?

answer.body: Cohesion is a measure of how closely the responsibilities of a component are related (degree of interaction within a component, higher is better). It characterizes the components internal dependencies.

question.body: What are the types of cohesion in descending level of cohesion (higher is better)?

answer.body: Functional, sequential, communicational, procedural, temporal, logical, coincidental.

question.body: What is the meaning of coincidental cohesion?

answer.body: Elements are grouped into components without signification relation between elements, i.e. by accident. It degrades maintainability and reusability, refactor by breaking it into several modules.

question.body: What is the meaning of logical cohesion?

answer.body: Elements are related logically but not functionally. Example: Read input from tape, disk, network (operations are related logically, but their function differs significantly).

question.body: What is temporal cohesion?

answer.body: The elements are independent but are activated at at the similar times. Example: initialization component (print some status info, open a database connection, verify licensing). This is a weak relationship, usually stronger ones exist that would increase maintainability and reusability.

question.body: What is procedural cohesion?

answer.body: Elements are grouped into a component only to ensure a particular order of execution. They are still weakly connected, degrading reusability.

question.body: What is communicational cohesion?

answer.body: Elements in a component operate on the same (external) data. Probably leads to blobs when considering large components, e.g. for database interaction.

question.body: What is sequential cohesion?

answer.body: The output of one part is input to another, data flows between parts (different from procedural cohesion).

question.body: What is functional cohesion?

answer.body: Every essential element to a single computation is contained in the component. These components often transform a single input into a single output. This is the ideal situation, with high reusability, testability, understandability, learnability and fault isolation. There are reduced regression faults and it is easy to extend the product.

question.body: What are some advantages expected from striving for low coupling and high cohesion? What should be avoided?

answer.body: Simpler communication, local decision making, easy correctness proofs, less change propagation, increased reusability and comprehensability. But don't overdo it.

question.body: What is the single responsibility principle?

answer.body: A class should only ever have one reason to change. If there are more, split the functionality. Should lead to cohesion at package/implementation level. Idea is simple, but can be hard to get right in practice.

question.body: What is responsability?

answer.body: A family of functions that serves one particular actor. It describes the core functionality of a class.

question.body: What is an actor in relation to a responsibility?

answer.body: An actor for a responsibility is the single source of change for that responsibility.

question.body: What is meant by separation of concerns?

answer.body: Talk about different things (features) in different places (non-functional and functional). Example: Business logic, presentation, data layer. Functional: related to low coupling/high cohesion.

question.body: What is the open/closed principle?

answer.body: Software entities should be open for extension but closed for modifications. Related to inheritance/polymorphism in object-oriented programming.

question.body: What is Liskov's substitution principle?

answer.body: If q(x) is a provable property of objects x of type t, then q(y) is provable for objects y of type s, where s subtype t. In words: Subtypes must be substitutable for base types, child classes must break parent's type definition.

question.body: What is a child class not allowed to do in order to conform to Liskov's substitution principle?

answer.body: It must not remove base class behavior, strengthen/weaken pre/post-conditions, violate base class invariants and require calling code to know it is different from the base type.

question.body: What is the Interface-Segregation Principle (ISP)?

answer.body: Clients should not be forced to depend on interfaces they do not use (small cohesive interfaces instead of fat interfaces). Related to single responsibility principle.

question.body: What is meant by 'anticipate change'?

answer.body: Build components in a way to minimize effort for potential future changes. Compromise between generality and specificity. Consider potential extensions/changes. Don't overdo it.

question.body: What is meant by "don't repeat yourself"?

answer.body: Every piece of knowledge and functionality must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system. If there are more than one they can diverge unexpectedly, lead to redundancy, increase complexity and ambiguity.

question.body: What are the four types of duplication?

answer.body: Imposed duplication (developers feel they have no choice), inadvertent duplication (developers don't realize they are duplicating information), impatient duplication (developers get lazy), inter-developer duplication (multiple people duplicate a piece of information).

question.body: What is the difference between internal and external quality?

answer.body: Good question! It is referenced in 2.1.3/2.1.4 slide 54 but apparently defined elsewhere.

question.body: What are the parts of a three tier architecture?

answer.body: Load balancer, web/application server, data server

question.body: What are some advantages/disadvantages of a three tier architecture?

answer.body: Effiecient, all in one hand, large attack surface (compromised web server equals compromised application)

question.body: What are the parts of a four tier architecture?

answer.body: Load balancer, web server, application server, data server

question.body: What are the benefits and drawbacks of four tier over three tier?

answer.body: Reduced attack surface (web/application servers separated). However, need to run more servers.

question.body: What s a demilitarized zone?

answer.body: An intermediate zone between the hostile internet and the internal network used for public servers. Compromising a public server does not gain access to the internal network.

question.body: What is an antipattern?

answer.body: A literary form describing a commonly occurring solution to a problem that generates negative consequences. This can occur due to insufficient knowledge, experience in solving particular type of problem, or applying a pattern in the wrong context.

question.body: What are some of the goals of a higher level vocabulary in relation to antipatterns?

answer.body: Simplify communication, enable concise description, provide real-world experience, provide remedy for most common predicaments, highlight the most common problems, provide the tools to recognize problems and causes. (Source: 2.2 slide 5)

question.body: What are the two types of antipatterns relating to software?

answer.body: Software development antipatterns (describe useful refactorings) and software architecture antipatterns (system-level structure).

question.body: What are the seven deadly sins in software practice?

answer.body: Haste (lack of time), apathy (lack of care), narrow-mindedness (refuse to accept widely-known solutions), sloth (easy answers), avarice (excessive complexity), ignorance (failure to seek understanding), pride/hubris (not-invented-here)

question.body: What are typical root causes and other causes of the blob antipattern?

answer.body: Root causes: sloth, haste. Other causes: lack of (object-oriented) architecture and architecture enforcement, too limited intervention and specified disaster.

question.body: What is the refactored solution of the blob antipattern?

answer.body: Refactoring of responsibilities

question.body: What is the functional decomposition antipattern?

answer.body: The result of experienced non-object-oriented developers developing in a object-oriented language, causing the program to look like a functional program using workarounds.

question.body: What are the root causes and other causes of the functional decomposition antipattern?

answer.body: Root causes: avarice, greed, sloth. Other causes: lack of object-oriented understanding, lack of architecture enforcement, specified disaster.

question.body: Which room is used to torture Winston Smith?

answer.body: Room 101

question.body: What is the auto-generated stovepipe antipattern?

answer.body: Occurs in an attempt to migrate existing software interfaces to distributed interfaces without modifying the software design. This generates a range of problems: Fine-grained communication between interfaces can be inefficient in distributed environments, existing interfaces may be implementation specific, applications might assume locality (access to filesystem etc.), and excessive complexity can arise in larger scale systems.

question.body: How can auto-generated stovepipe be refactored?

answer.body: By reengineering interfaces and creating a coarse-grained object model for communication.

question.body: What is the golden hammer antipattern?

answer.body: When a team has experience in a particular solution approach and attempts to solve any new problems using the familiar approach, even though it might not be suitable for the specific problem instance.

question.body: What are the root causes of the golden hammer antipattern and what are some other causes?

answer.body: Root causes: ignorance, pride, narrow-mindedness. Other causes: several successes with a particular approach, large investment in a technology, isolation of group, reliance on proprietary features.

question.body: What is the refactored solution of the golden hammer antipattern?

answer.body: Expand your horizons

question.body: What is the design by committee antipattern?

answer.body: A design that was influenced by many stakeholders, leading to excessive complexity in features/variations. May be found in some standards.

question.body: What are some root causes and other typical causes of the design by committee antipattern?

answer.body: Root causes: pride, avarice. Other typical causes: lack of project architect, bad meeting or software process, attempt to make everybody happy, gold plating (modifications based on proprietary interests)

question.body: What is the refactored solution to the design by committee antipattern?

answer.body: Meeting facilitation. Use all the standard methods to hold coordinated meetings.

question.body: What is a typical example of a design by committee used in the lecture?

answer.body: The SQL standard, which started out in 1989 as a 115 page document, then had a 580 page 1992 standardization called SQL92 and died before SQL3.

question.body: What are the antipatterns covered in the lecture?

answer.body: Blob, functional decomposition, auto-generated stovepipe, golden hammer, design by committee

question.body: What are some technical reasons why reuse often does not work?

answer.body: Often done in-the-small/at code level, with limited scope, and unsystematicaly. Often, the consideration of non functional requirements, quality characteristics, dependencies, correctness and completeness are unclear or unfulfilled.

question.body: What are some organizational reasons why reuse often does not work?

answer.body: Reuse rarely planned or done too late, lack of motivation/incentive (NIH), lack of defined interfaces or system/requirement knowledge, lack of marketplaces and standards.

question.body: What is a tradeoff conflict in reuse?

answer.body: Flexibility/Stability: Too flexible requires expensive adaptations, too inflexible improves stability but prevents reuse.

question.body: What are some architectural principles that help support reuse?

answer.body: Modularity, loose coupling/high cohesion, information hiding, separation of concerns.

question.body: What types of reuse are there?

answer.body: Opportunistic (ad-hoc) reuse, planned (structured) reuse.

question.body: What is meant by clone-and-own?

answer.body: A common reuse practice that involves cloning some existing component/code and developing it independently from there on.

question.body: What are some problems with ad-hoc reuse?

answer.body: It does not scale due to lack of organization and management. Significant effort goes into search, evaluation, adaptation, integration, clone detection, maintenance.

question.body: What types of structured reuse are there?

answer.body: Configurable software solutions (essential functionality parameterized, no code changes), software product lines (construction kits), software frameworks (reusable libraries of artifacts, not standalone).

question.body: What are variability subjects/objects?

answer.body: Subject: Variable item of real world or variable property of item. Object: A particular instance of variability subject.

question.body: What is internal/external variability?

answer.body: Internal: Variability of domain artifacts that is invisible to customers. External: Variability of domain artifacts that is visible to customers.

question.body: What is the binding time converning variability?

answer.body: The moment that variability is resolved.

question.body: What is meant by managed variability?

answer.body: Defining variability, managing variable artifacts, resolving variability, maintaining trace information.

question.body: What are some shortcomings of modeling variability in traditional software development models?

answer.body: Hard to keep information consistent, hard to determine relation in variable requirements to variable design, realization, test, overloading of existing models, different concepts in different tools.

question.body: What is an orthogonal variability model?

answer.body: Defines variability of software product line. Relates to variability defined in other models.

question.body: What type of diagram is used to model variability?

answer.body: A feature diagram

question.body: What is a variation point/variant?

answer.body: Variation point: Representation of variability subject, including domain artifacts and contextual information. Variant is representation of variability objects within domain artifacts.

question.body: Label the numbered items in the feature diagram:

answer.body: 1: Mandatory 2: Optional 3: Alternative 4: Or 5: Requires 6: Excludes

question.body: Whatprogramming paradigms can support variability at code level?

answer.body: Conditional compilation, polymorphism, aspect-oriented programming

question.body: What is a product line architecture?

answer.body: A generic software architecture for a product line, containing the architecture for all line members.

question.body: What is the difference between a normal architecture and a product line architecture?

answer.body: The product line architecture covers additional conerns: common/variable parts, specific instances, how is support ensured for all members?

question.body: What is a software product line?

answer.body: A software product line is a set of applications with a common architecture and shared components, with each application specialized to reflect different requirements.

question.body: What is Software Product Line Engineering?

answer.body: The adoption of traditional product line approaches for building applications for mass customization through managed variability to systematically model commonalities and the differences in software applications.

question.body: What types of specialization exist for a software product line?

answer.body: Platform specialization (OS, etc.), environment specialization (operating environment, e.g. communication equipment), functional specialization (different customer requirements), process specialization (different business process)

question.body: What are some reasong for product line engineering?

answer.body: Cost, quality, time to market (special emphasis), focus on functionality (by application development based on pre-built configurable components) instead of technology.

question.body: What are the rules of thumb for cost reduction with PLE?

answer.body: Investment: 1x-2x system cost (Cost for 1st system: 2x-3x). Saving begins between 2nd/3rd product.

question.body: What problem is tackled by PLE?

answer.body: Software companies develop multiple products in business area, that grow over time, are similar but not identical, where from scratch development is unproductive.

question.body: What is an advantage of PLE when it comes to change?

answer.body: Changes can propagate within the product or across multiple products.

question.body: Fill in the blanks:

answer.body: 1: Application engineering, 2: Family engineering, 3: feed-forward, 4: feedback

question.body: What is family/domain engineering?

answer.body: Identification of commonalities, definition and construction of reusable artifacts considering economically viable variability, definition of set of applications (scope) of the software product line.

question.body: What is application engineering?

answer.body: Development of individual products based on PL artifact base, instantiating varibilities according to requirements.

question.body: What is the product line artifact base?

answer.body: Capture characteristics of PL artifact, contains product model, process model, resources

question.body: What is scoping in relation to PLE?

answer.body: The process of identifying and bounding areas (subdomains, existing assets) and capabilities (features) of the product line where investment into reuse is economically viable and beneficial to development.

question.body: Which aspects need to be considered in PLE scoping?

answer.body: Products, domains, featuers, assets?

question.body: What is the product feature matrix?

answer.body: A matrix showing features in subdomains and the products supported by it.

question.body: What are some arguments for/against PLE?

answer.body: +: Reduced cost, increased quality, decreased time to market, better understanding of domain, economic structured reuse. -: high up-front investment, scoping needs strong domain knowledge, limited success in practice.

question.body: What is a software framework?

answer.body: Conventions, principles, and practices for the description of architectures established within a specific domain of application and/or community of stakeholders.

question.body: Find _. A _ provides support for generic features that are likely to be used in all applications of a similar type as well as reuse of specific classes. A _ supports design reuse, it provides a skeleton architecture. A _ is language specific.

answer.body: Framework

question.body: What is the difference between software libraries and frameworks in relation to their extension points?

answer.body: Class libraries use the call-down principle (user code calls library). Framworks use the call-back principle (framework calls user code).

question.body: What is a reference architecture?

answer.body: An abstract software architecture for a specific application area, defining structures and types of software elements, their interactions and responsibilities applicable for all systems of a domain.

question.body: What are the types of reference architectures?

answer.body: Functional (structure functionality throughout functional areas), logical (defines layers/components), technical (defines language/infrastructure).

question.body: What defines a good test case?

answer.body: One that finds a potential bug with cost effectiveness (design, execution, evaluation, localization, fix)

question.body: What are some difficult systems to test any why?

answer.body: GUIs (how can a test observe and control?), systems with databases (underlying state changes), cloud-based systems (distribution, differences to development environment), non-deterministic systems (same input different output)

question.body: What is observability and controllability?

answer.body: Observability: Can everything relevant (internal state, diagnosis log, etc.) be observed by the tester? Controllability: Can the state of the program be modified to facilitate the test easily?

question.body: What is the definition of testability and to what concepts of software engineering is it applied?

answer.body: Degree to which a system/component/requirement facilitates establishment of test criteria and performance of tests to determine whether they have been met.

question.body: What is the black-box/white-box approach to measuring testability?

answer.body: Black box: difficulty developing a test suite for some test selection criterion C. White box: difficulty developing a test suite for a program P and test selection criterion C.

question.body: What is the probabilistic definition of testability in relation to finding bugs?

answer.body: Testability is the likelihood of a program to fail with the next test if software includes a bug (this is also influenced by the quality of the test cases, not just by the system).

question.body: What other verification and validation techniques are there when the system/module shows poor testability?

answer.body: Review and formal verification

question.body: What are the two types of information loss and what is the problem of information loss with testability?

answer.body: Implicit loss: many input values lead to the same output value. Explicit loss: Internal state is not verified after execution of a module. This loss leads to a decreased probability of finding a bug, as it is not propagated to the output. The domain/range ratio (|input domain|/|output domain|) correlates with implicit losses.

question.body: What is the tradeoff between testability and modularity?

answer.body: Testable systems need to be able to access the inner state of the system under test (or otherwise observe it well), while modularity wants to hide as much internal information as possible (information hiding).

question.body: How can a program be modified to measure testability of a system and or the quality of a test suite?

answer.body: A defect that changes the program's inner state can be injected into the program and the test suit executed. The likelihood that the output is changed/caught by the test suite correlates with testability.

question.body: What types of version control are there?

answer.body: Local, centralized, distributed

question.body: What are some of the advantages of centralized version control and distributed version control?

answer.body: Centralized: easy to maintain single server. Distributed: no single point of control, private version control possible

question.body: What differences are there in how svn/git store changes?

answer.body: SVN stores a list of file-based delta. Git stores snapshots of a directory tree.

question.body: What three stages for files does git have?

answer.body: Modified (unstaged), staged, committed

question.body: What is a branch in git?

answer.body: A named pointer to a commit using its hash

question.body: What is continuous integration?

answer.body: A fully automated and reproducible build, including testing, that runs many times a day to integrate changes often.

question.body: What are some reasons to use continuous integration?

answer.body: Reduced risk, integrated quality assurance, rapid feedback, availability of stable release

question.body: What is continuous delivery?

answer.body: A software engineering approach in which teams produce valuable software in short cycles that can be reliably released at any time.

question.body: What are some benefits of continuous delivery?

answer.body: Time to market, customer satisfaction, productivity and efficiency, building the right product, reliable release

question.body: What is the difference between continuous delivery and continuous deployment?

answer.body: In continuous deployment, the deploy step is triggered automatically. Every change therefore automatically gets put into production, resulting in many deployments per day. In continuous deliver, this step happens manually.

question.body: What is a deployment pipeline?

answer.body: An automated manifestation of your process for getting software from version control to users.

question.body: What is a smoke test?

answer.body: Smoke testing is preliminary testing to reveal simple failures severe enough to reject a prospective software release.

question.body: What eight deployment automation patterns were covered in the lecture?

answer.body: Repository (version control all relevant files for reproducability), scripted deployment (all deployment is automated), single command (a single command generates working software for users), externalized configuration (variable values externalized into build-time properties), tokenize configuration (token values in config files are replaced during scripted deployment by values from the externalized configuration), template verifier (single template file for all target environments), unified deployment (single deployment script for all platforms and environments), remote deployment (centralized machine for deploying to multiple target environments).

question.body: What is blue-green deployment?

answer.body: A technique where two live environments are used. The second (offline) environment is deployed to, then the online/offline environments are switched.

question.body: What is virtualization?

answer.body: A combination of software/hardware engineering that creates virtual machines, an abstraction that allows a single machine to act as if it were multiple machines.

question.body: What are some advantages of virtual machines?

answer.body: Increased software compatibility, isolation, consolidation, and resource pooling.

question.body: What is the N x N compatibility nightmare? How is it solved?

answer.body: Multiplicity of software stacks and multiplicity of hardware environments causes compatibility issues. Containers (docker) can help deploy anything into any environment.

question.body: What is cloud computing?

answer.body: A specialized form of distributed computing that introduces utilization models for remotely provisioning scalable and measured resources.

question.body: What are some goals of cloud computing?

answer.body: Increased availability, reliability, reduced investments, proportional costs, increased scalability

question.body: What are the actors in the cloud reference architecture?

answer.body: Cloud consumer, provider, auditor, broker, carrier (ISP)

question.body: What are the essential characterstics of cloud computing?

answer.body: On-demand self-service, broad network access, resource pooling, rapid elasticity, measured service

question.body: What is software as a service?

answer.body: The ability for a consumer to use the provider's applications running on cloud infrastructure.

question.body: What is Platform as a Service?

answer.body: The ability for a consumer to deploy consumer-created/acquired applications to cloud infrastructure using programming languages, libraries, services, and tools supported by the provider.

question.body: What is Infrastructure as a Service?

answer.body: The ability for a consumer to provision computing resources (storage, network, etc) where the consumer can deploy and run arbitrary software on cloud infrastructure.

question.body: What deployment models are there for cloud infrastructure?

answer.body: Public (cloud open for use by general public), private (single organization use, owned and managed by organization, on-site/off-site), outsourced private (single organization use, owned and managed by third-party, on-site/off-site), community (multi organization use), and hybrid (composition of multiple models) cloud.

question.body: Which fundamental cloud architecture exists?

answer.body: Workload distribution architecture (horizontal scaling, balancer), resource pooling architecture (group identical resources), dynamic scalability (horizontal/vertical/relocation) (dynamic allocation from resource pools for variable utilization), service load balancing architecture (like workload distribution architecture, specifically for scaling cloud service implementations)

question.body: What are some challenges in cloud architectures?

answer.body: Confidentiality, integrity, availability, privacy, increased attack surface, auditability, forensics, legal issues, trust issues.

question.body: What is the difference between safety and security?

answer.body: Safety ("Betriebssicherheit") is concerned with protecting the environment from the system while security ("Angriffssicherheit") is concerned with protecting the system from the environment.

question.body: What is the goal of the safety threshold concept?

answer.body: The goal is to determine how safe is 'safe enough' without over- or under-engineering a product.

question.body: What is risk?

answer.body: Risk is the combination of the probability of occurrence of harm and the severity of that harm.

question.body: What is risk aversion?

answer.body: The reluctance of people to accept a bargain with an uncertain payoff rather than another bargain with more certain, but possibly lower, expected payoff.

question.body: What is scale aversion?

answer.body: The tendency to want greater protection where consequences are high.

question.body: What is the ALARP principle?

answer.body: The "As Low As is Reasonably Practical" principle defines three risk regions: intolerable region, tolerable/ALARP region, and the broadly acceptable region.

marks.mark: As Low As is Reasonably Practical

question.body: What is the goal of risk reduction?

answer.body: The goal is to reduce risk to a tolerable level by combining multiple methods/means (not to zero).

question.body: What is the definition of safety?

answer.body: The absence of unacceptable/unreasonable risk.

question.body: How are faults, errors, and failures connected?

answer.body: Faults manifest as an error and an error ultimately may cause a failure.

question.body: What is a fault?

answer.body: A fault is an abnormal condition that can cause an element or an item to fail.

question.body: What is an error?

answer.body: An error is the discrepancy between a computed, observed or measured value or condition and the true, specified or theoretically correct value or condition.

question.body: What is a failure?

answer.body: A failure is the termination of the ability of an element, to perform a function as required.

question.body: What is the difference between systematic and random issues?

answer.body: A random issue is caused by physical processes such as damage or fatigue, while a systematic issue is caused by specification or design issues, or hardware wear-out.

question.body: What is a cascading failure?

answer.body: A failure of an element causing another element of the same item to fail.

question.body: What is a common cause failure?

answer.body: A failure of two or more elements resulting form a single specific event or root cause.

question.body: What does functional safety cover?

answer.body: Functional safety focuses on the hazards and risks originating from the function of an (E/E) system.

question.body: What is the lifecycle approach to functional safety?

answer.body: The various life cycle activities and defenses against systematic failures that are necessary to achieve functional safety occurring at different stages in the design and operation of the system.

question.body: What does the lifecycle approach to functional safety emphasize?
What are the two safety concepts in the lifecycle approach to functional safety?

answer.body: The functional safety concept is a statement of the functionality to achieve the safety goal. The technical safety concept is a statement of how this functionality is implemented in hardware or software.

question.body: What are the objectives of safety analysis?

answer.body: The objectives are: ...to examine consequences of faults and failures on functions, behavior and design of items/elements. ...to provide information on conditions/causes that could lead to violation of a safety goal or safety requirement. ...to contribute to identification of new functional or non-functional hazards not previously identified during the hazard analysis and risk assessment.

question.body: What are the differences between qualitative and quantitative safety analysis methods?

answer.body: Qualitative methods require knowledge of relevant fault models and can identify failures. Quantitative methods also require knowledge about relevant fault models and additionally about quantitative hardware failure rates. They can complement qualitative analyses and are able to predict the frequency of random hardware failures. Thus they are used to verify hardware designs.

question.body: What is the difference between inductive and deductive safety analysis methods?

answer.body: Inductive methods are bottom-up (fault to failure) methods, while deductive methods are top-down (failure to fault) methods.

question.body: What is the usual relation between inductive and deductive safety analysis methods?

answer.body: They are usually complementary.

question.body: What inductive safety analysis method was discussed in the lecture?

answer.body: Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA)

question.body: What deductive safety analysis method was discussed in the lecture?

answer.body: Fault Tree Analysis (FTA)

question.body: What is the most important FMEA terminology? Also briefly explain it.

answer.body: Failure Mode: Manner in which a component could potentially fail to meet design intent. Failure Effects: Effects of the failure mode on the function as perceived by the customer. Causes: Indications of a design weakness, the consequence of which is the failure mode. Detection/Prevention Measures: Activities which will assure the design adequacy for the failure cause under consideration.

question.body: What quantitative variables does FMEA consider? Also briefly explain them.

answer.body: Severity: Rates the severity of a potential failure effect. Occurrence: Rates the likelihood that the failure will occur. Detection: Rates the likelihood that the problem will not be detected before it reaches the end-user. Risk Priority Number: Severity * Occurrence * Detection

question.body: What is the goal of FTA?

answer.body: The goal is to identify all conditions that lead to a system failure.

question.body: What is the procedure of FTA?

answer.body: Define the system under scrutiny. Determine undesired events (top event). Identify event or series of events that lead to the top level event.

question.body: What are the CIA security properties? Explain them briefly.

answer.body: Confidentiality: Can non-authorized parties see data? Integrity: Has data been altered? Availability: Is data always accessible?

question.body: What security properties other than CIA did the lecture cover?

answer.body: Non-repudiation: Impossibility to inappropriately deny an action. Authenticity: An action assigned to an entity was actually performed by that entity. Auditability: Ability to reconstruct earlier states of a system. Accountability: Ability to assign responsibility for actions to an entity. Privacy: Refers to security of personal information. Anonymity: The identity of an entity is hidden; one aspect of privacy.

question.body: What effect does increasing security usually have on usability?

answer.body: It decreases usability.

question.body: What four kinds of factors have to be leveraged for security?

answer.body: Technical: e.g. cryptography Organizational: e.g. defining responsibilities People-related: e.g. education Legal: e.g. liability regulations

question.body: What five design principles for designing secure systems were covered in the lecture?

answer.body: Least privilege: Every subject should not have more privileges than necessary. Complete mediation: Access to every object must be controlled in a way not circumventable. Secure, fail-safe defaults: Security mechanisms should start in a secure state and return to a secure default state in case of failures. Compartmentalization: Organize resources into groups, isolated from others except for limited, controlled means of communication. Minimum exposure: Minimize the attack surface a system presents to a potential adversary.

question.body: What kinds of implementation-level attacks were discussed in the lecture?

answer.body: SQL injections, cross-site scripting (XSS), and buffer-overflow attacks.

question.body: What are the three different types of XSS?

answer.body: Non-persistent (or reflective) attacks: Malicious code in a link that goes to the server and back. Persistent attacks: Malicious code in server store, sent from server to client. DOM based attacks: Server web application not involved.

question.body: What is an attack tree and how is it used?

answer.body: An attack tree is a fault tree considering the role of attackers. Nodes are assigned attributes such as possibilities, probabilities, and estimated impact. This identifies the most important attacks to deploy countermeasures for.

question.body: What is the BSI baseline protection?

answer.body: It is basically a catalog of what should be done in most situations in order to secure standard infrastructure.

question.body: What is the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)?

answer.body: The GDPR applies to every organization dealing with european citizens and regulates how these organizations have to handle private data.

question.body: With which four goals may information security interfere with?

answer.body: Performance, usability, time to market, and cost objectives.

question.body: What is a distributed system?

answer.body: A distributed system consists of physically disjoint compute resources, interconnected by a network.

question.body: What are a five of the characteristics of distributed systems covered in the lecture?

answer.body: Reliability, Availability, Heterogeneity, Openness, Security, Scalability, Fault-tolerance and failure handling, Concurrency, Transparency, Predictable performance

question.body: How are reliability and availability of a system related?

answer.body: A reliable system has high availability but an available system may or may not be reliable.

question.body: What are four of the aspects, that overall transparency depends on?

answer.body: Access: Hide differences in data representation. Location: Hide where a resource is located. Migration: Hide that a resource may move to another location. Relocation: Hide that a resource may be moved to another location while in use. Replication Hide that a resource is replicated. Concurrency: Hide that a resource may be shared by several competitive users. Failure: Hide the failure and recovery of a resource.

question.body: What is middleware?

answer.body: Middleware comprises services and abstractions that facilitate design, development and deployment of distributed applications in heterogeneous, networked environments.

question.body: What does middleware deal with?

answer.body: Capturing common functionalities (like message passing), interoperability, and system integration.

question.body: What are the three layers of the middleware stack?

answer.body: Application layer; Middleware layer; IT infrastructure

question.body: What is the main purpose of database-centric architectures?

answer.body: The purpose is to handle data access and update.

question.body: What is a typical mainframe model?

answer.body: The mainframe model uses the mainframe as a central repository for information as well as processing for every application. Terminals enable input/output into the applications. All administration takes place on the mainframe itself.

question.body: What are some advantages of a typical mainframe model?

answer.body: Hardware maintenance cost reduction; Single point of administration; One type of administrative skill set; Simple architecture and low bandwidth requirements

question.body: What are some disadvantages of a typical mainframe model?

answer.body: Single point of failure; Character-based application only; Bottlenecks due to time-sharing systems

question.body: What layers does a typical three-layered client/server architecture consist of?

answer.body: Client, Web server, and Data sources.

question.body: What are some advantages of a typical three-layered client/server architecture?

answer.body: Reduced hardware costs; No single point of failure; Flexibility; Scalable architecture

question.body: What are some disadvantages of a typical three-layered client/server architecture?

answer.body: Heightened administrative costs; Increased security risk; Lack of centralized backup

question.body: What is a database view?

answer.body: A view is a virtual relation (e.g. table) that does not actually exist in the database but is produced upon request, at the time of request.

question.body: What purposes can a database view fulfill?
What are some advantages of database views?

answer.body: Data independence; Improved security; Reduced complexity; Convenience; Customization; Data integrity

question.body: What are some disadvantages of database views?

answer.body: Update restriction; Structure restriction; Performance

question.body: What is the difference between a (stored) procedure and a function in a database-centric architecture?

answer.body: Procedures and functions are identical except that functions always return a value while procedures do not.

question.body: What are some advantages of procedures (and functions) in a database-centric architecture?

answer.body: Extensibility; Reusability; Maintainability; Aid abstraction; Improved testability; Improved performance; Improved security

question.body: What are some disadvantages of procedures (and functions) in a database-centric architecture?

answer.body: Limited coding functionality; Portability issues; Reduced flexibility and agility

question.body: What is data warehousing?

answer.body: It is a collection of methods, techniques and tools which is used to support knowledge workers such as senior managers, directors, managers, and business analysts to conduct data analyses that help with performing decision-making processes and improving information resources.

question.body: What are the three features of a data warehouse?

answer.body: It is subject-oriented, integrated and consistent, and shows its evolution over time and it is non-volatile.

question.body: How is data from operational systems prepared for a data warehouse?

answer.body: It is extracted, cleansed, transformed and aggregated before it is loaded into the data warehouse.

question.body: What is a data mart?

answer.body: It is a subset or an aggregation of the data stored to a primary data warehouse. It includes information relevant to a specific business area, corporate department, or category of users.

question.body: How do top-down and bottom-up approaches to data warehousing differ?

answer.body: Top-down approaches start by designing the data warehouse first, then the data marts. Bottom-up approaches start by designing the data marts. Then the data marts may be integrated into a data warehouse or no warehouse is created at all.

question.body: What does OLAP stand for?

answer.body: Online analytical processing

question.body: What does OLTP stand for?

answer.body: Online transaction processing

question.body: What are some essential differences between OLTP and OLAP?

answer.body: OLTP is application-oriented current isolated data and used in day to day operations by lots of IT professionals. OLAP is lots of subject-oriented historical consolidated data used by knowledge workers for decision support.

question.body: What is an OLAP data cube?

answer.body: It is a data analysis tool in OLAP allowing to use generalized GROUP BY queries and to aggregate facts based on chosen dimensions.

question.body: What are the four interactive OLAP operations?

answer.body: Slice, Dice, Drill down/up, Aggregation

question.body: What are some advantages of a data cube?

answer.body: They are good for visualization, multidimensional and intuitive.

question.body: What are the three data warehouse architectures covered in the lecture?

answer.body: Central architecture, Federated architecture, and Tiered architecture.

question.body: What characterizes a central data warehouse architecture?

answer.body: All data is in one, central data warehouse that is directly accessed. This is easy to manage.

question.body: What characterizes a federated data warehouse architecture?

answer.body: Data is stored in separate data marts, aimed at special departments. The data warehouse is logical (i.e. virtual) and the clients access the data marts. Performance is increased due to distribution.

question.body: What characterizes a tiered data warehouse architecture?

answer.body: The central data warehouse is materialized and data is distributed to data marts in one or more tiers, being aggregated/reduced as it moves through tiers. Clients access the data marts. The This ensures great performance but is complex to manage.

question.body: What are some issues with data warehousing?

answer.body: Metadata management; DW project management; High HW+SW cost; Ethical issues

question.body: What is big data?

answer.body: Big data refers to datasets whose size is beyond the ability of typical database software tools to capture, store, manage, and analyze.

question.body: What is scalability?

answer.body: Scalability is the ability of a system, network, or process to handle a growing amount of work in a capable manner or its ability to be enlarged to accommodate that growth.

question.body: What are the two types of scaling and how do they differ?

answer.body: Vertical scaling means replacing an existing IT resource with another with higher or lower capacity. Horizontal scaling means allocating or releasing IT resources that are of the same type.

question.body: What are some advantages of horizontal and vertical scaling?

answer.body: Horizontal scaling is less expensive, fully automates scaling, and is not limited by maximum hardware capacity. Vertical scaling does not require additional IT resources.

question.body: What is another name for horizontal partitioning?

answer.body: Sharding

question.body: What is sharding in the context of big data?

answer.body: The data store is partitioned into shards having the same schema by some primary field. Each shard is placed on a separate node in a cluster that spreads the read and write operations.

question.body: What are the three sharding strategies?

answer.body: The lookup strategy uses a map that routes a request to the shard that contains that data by using the shard key. The range strategy groups related items together in the same shard and orders them by shard key. The hash strategy treats the shards as hash buckets in order to reduce the chance of hotspots in the data.

question.body: What are NoSQL databases?

answer.body: Next generation databases mostly addressing some of the points: being non-relational, distributed, open-source and horizontally scalable.

question.body: What does NoSQL stand for?

answer.body: Not only SQL

question.body: What is a key-value store?

answer.body: Data is stored in unstructured records consisting of a key and the values associated with that record.

question.body: In what case do key-value stores have poor performance and how can this limitation be overcome?

answer.body: Key-value stores have poor to cases that require processing key ranges. Ordered key-value stores can overcome this limitation.

question.body: What is Bigtable?

answer.body: Bigtable is a distributed storage system for managing structured data that is designed to scale to a very large size by Google. It maps two arbitrary string values (row and column key) and a timestamp into an associated arbitrary byte array.

question.body: What are some advantages of Bigtable?

answer.body: Performance, Scalability, Availability, Flexibility, High speed retrieval, Data reliability, Storage size, Versioning, Suitability for many data additions

question.body: What are some disadvantages of Bigtable?

answer.body: No support for multi-row transactions; No join functionality; Not suitable for many data modifications

question.body: What is a document-oriented database?

answer.body: It is a database not enforcing a schema. Each record and its associated data is thought of as a document.

question.body: What are some advantages of document-oriented databases?

answer.body: Improved performance by using sequential read (because all data regarding an object is at the same position on the disk); Easier application logic (because object models can be turned into documents)

question.body: What is a graph database?

answer.body: A graph database stores connections as first class citizens, readily available for any join-like navigation operation. Accessing those already persistent connections is an efficient, constant-time operation.

question.body: What is the core consistency rule in a graph database?

answer.body: No broken links.

question.body: What are some advantages of graph databases?

answer.body: No penalties for complex runtime queries; Efficient scale-up and billions of nodes in one database on moderate hardware

question.body: What are some issues with NoSQL?

answer.body: Data is generally duplicated; No standardized schema; No standard format for queries; No standard query language; Application layer needs to enforce data integrity

question.body: What three properties can no distributed data system achieve at the same time?

answer.body: Consistency, Availability, and Partition Tolerance.

question.body: What is MapReduce?

answer.body: MapReduce is an algorithm used to process large data amounts in parallel. The map function iterates over records and extracts something of interest from each, creating key-value pairs. The reduce function then aggregates the key-value pairs by key, producing a final output.

question.body: What are the three possible intents of a middleware message?

answer.body: Command message: The sender tells the receiver what code to run. Document message: The sender transmits one of its data structures to the receiver. Event message: Notifying the receiver of a change in the sender.

question.body: What are the three patterns of message queues?

answer.body: Point-to-point pattern: It ensures that only one receiver consumes any given message. Publish-subscribe pattern: Routes messages from publisher (source) to subscribers (sinks). Datatype pattern: Uses separate datatype queues for each datatype.

question.body: What are some advantages of message queues?

answer.body: Give recipient control of when to process messages; More robust to failures (because recipients do not need to be up and running when a message is sent); Messages may have an expiration date; Queues can be shared among multiple applications

question.body: What are some advantages of message-oriented middleware?

answer.body: Remote communication; Decoupling of systems; Platform/application integration; Asynchronous communication protocol; Solves issue of throttling

question.body: What re some disadvantages of message-oriented middleware?

answer.body: Some scenarios require synchronous solutions; Message sequence issues (queues do not guarantee when a message will be delivered)

question.body: What is the purpose of Enterprise Application Integration (EAI)?

answer.body: EAI is intended to integrate services provided by different middlewares.

question.body: What is a message broker?

answer.body: Message brokers act as a broker among system entities. This factors the message routing logic out of the senders and places it into the middleware. Applications publish their messages to the middleware and the middleware sends a copy of the message to every subscribed application.

question.body: What are some challenges concerning messages brokers?

answer.body: Scalability; Security: Growing number of SSL certificates has to be managed.; Monitoring and debugging; Maintenance: Broker cannot be updated without affecting the clients.

question.body: What are the characteristics of a reactive system?

answer.body: Responsive; Resilient; Elastic; Message-driven

question.body: What is the actor model?

answer.body: The actor model represents objects and their interactions, resembling human organizations and built upon the laws of physics.

question.body: What does the actor model embody?

answer.body: It embodies processing, storage, and communication.

question.body: What are the axioms of the actor model?

answer.body: When an actor receives a message it can: Make local decisions, create new actors, send messages to actors it knows, or designate how it should handle the next message it receives.

question.body: What are some advantages of the actor model?
What are some disadvantages of the actor model?

answer.body: Message-passing is slower; Actors do not work well when synchronous shared-state behavior is required; Steep learning curve; Dealing when an actor crashes, a message is lost, or an external message is introduced

question.body: What is an object broker?

answer.body: It is an extended Remote Procedure Call (RPC) paradigm for the object-oriented world.

question.body: What is CORBA?

answer.body: Common Object Request Broker Architecture is a standardized specification of an object broker.

question.body: What are the tiers of the Java EE multi-tier architecture (and where are they run)?

answer.body: Client tier (on client), web tier (on JEE server), business tier (on JEE server), and enterprise information system tier (on database server).

question.body: What are the kinds of containers used in the Java EE multi-tier architecture (and where are they run)?

answer.body: Application client container (on client), EJB container (on JEE server), and web container (on JEE server).

question.body: What is an EJB?

answer.body: An Enterprise Java Bean realizes business logic and is deployed within EJB containers.

question.body: What are the different types of EJB?

answer.body: Session beans: Only one per client and live for just one session. Message-driven beans: For asynchronous processing of messages. Entity beans: Deprecated.

question.body: What are the contents of an EJB?

answer.body: Enterprise bean class: Implements the business methods and any lifecycle callback methods. Business interfaces: Define the business methods implemented by the enterprise bean class. Helper classes: Other required utility classes.

question.body: How can EJBs be accessed?

answer.body: No-interface view: Exposes the public methods to clients. Business interface: Standard Java interface that contains the business methods of the EJB.

question.body: What is the role of the Java Persistence API (JPA)?

answer.body: It allows persistent deployment of POJOs to relational databases. Replaces entity beans.

question.body: What is the JMS?

answer.body: Java Message Service is a message-oriented middleware for Java.

question.body: What does a JMS message consist of?

answer.body: Header, Properties (optional), and Body.

question.body: What Java Web Components were discussed in the lecture?

answer.body: Java Servlet: Process HTTP requests and generate replies. JavaServer Page: Text-based documents with special JSP tags that contain java code (deprecated). JavaServer Face: MVC pattern based web framework.

question.body: What is the difference between a tier and a layer?

answer.body: A layer is a logical structuring for software elements, while a tier is a physical structuring mechanism for system infrastructure.

question.body: What deployment strategies did the lecture name?

answer.body: Non-distributed deployment, distributed deployment, load balanced cluster, and failover cluster.

question.body: What are some advantages of non-distributed deployment?
